image.altText: Lauren Hemp runs past Clare Polkinghorne

items.synopsis: Samantha Kerr's unbelievable strike brought Stadium Australia to its feet — but minutes later, the Matildas were left deflated thanks to the pressure from the player of the game.

title.children: Just minutes after Sam Kerr's stunning strike, England's star of the match knocked the wind out of Australia's World Cup hopes

image.altText: A group of Matildas players and coaches form a heart on the pitch as they talk after a big match.

items.synopsis: A Sam Kerr wonder goal, sure, but Australia's World Cup run is over as England ran out 3-1 winners in the Women's World Cup semi-final — here's how the internet reacted.

title.children: 'That’s a gift': How the internet reacted to the Matildas' heartbreaking 3-1 loss to England

image.altText: a group of protesters gather at a stage in high vis

items.synopsis: Thousands of protesters march on Labor's national conference, causing traffic chaos in Queensland's capital.

title.children: Thousands of protesters march on Labor's national conference in Brisbane

image.altText: A man in a mask sitting on a chair.

items.synopsis: An uprising inspired and led by women was met with a swift crackdown. Now, young dissidents speak to the ABC in a series of interviews conducted in secret.

title.children: 'Friends, it has just started': A brutal crackdown only pushed their rebellion underground

image.altText: A blurred car driving on the highway with petrol prices showing behind it

items.synopsis: Australians are feeling more pain at the petrol pump as prices rise to the highest level so far this year, and analysts say the rising prices are likely to stay for "the next few weeks" at least.

title.children: Motorists are paying more for petrol now than they have all year — and it's likely to stay that way for weeks

image.altText: a young woman holding hospital equipment

items.synopsis: Ivy Belavy wanted a job that would help people. But the 19-year-old, who has a disability, found it difficult to get work.

title.children: Ivy found employers rarely 'had the patience for her'. Now she works in aged care

image.altText: A phone screen showing a mail app with two notifications

items.synopsis: Phishing is the most commonly reported scam in Australia, with scammers harvesting tens of millions of dollars every year from unsuspecting victims.

title.children: It was the most reported scam in Australia last year. Here's how phishing works

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

items.synopsis: The rejection of a rental freeze at yesterday's National Cabinet means the push from the Greens has hit a dead end. Will the party join the Coalition to vote down the government's $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund? We'll see, writes David Speers.

title.children: Rental freeze hits a dead end, squashed by the orthodox view

image.altText: Australia's football superstar Sam Kerr looks sad but gives a thumbs up to the crowd after the Matildas Women's World Cup loss.

items.synopsis: The Matildas call for improved funding for football and urge their plethora of new-found fans to stay on the bandwagon after the Women's World Cup.

title.children: 'We need funding everywhere': Sam Kerr, Matildas teammates call for investment, support for football after World Cup run

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green holds her face in her hands with the result on the scoreboard behind

items.synopsis: The Matildas wanted to create their own Cathy Freeman moment. They did — but not in quite the way they expected.

title.children: Matildas' semifinal loss to England was not about the finish, but the run

image.altText: Indigenous man with grey hair and one eye looks into the distance

items.synopsis: Djiniyini Gondarra, a spiritual leader from north-east Arnhem Land, wants to see his decades-long calls for a treaty fulfilled. But he doesn't believe a Voice will deliver it.

title.children: He's been described as Australia's Gandhi. And this civil rights leader is planning to vote No to a Voice

image.altText: Composite image headshots of Julie Bishop, Mathias Cormann, Anthony Albanese and Katy Gallagher all with WRONG printed undern

items.synopsis: This week marks 10 years of Fact Check at the ABC and the 600 verdicts offer an insight into our political system, writes RMIT ABC Fact Check's Matt Martino.

title.children: After a decade of being fact checked, politicians on both sides have continually repeated this incorrect claim

image.altText: A computer-generated graphic of Anthony Albanese at a podium. Around him, a crowd of people hold up pamphlets.

items.synopsis: Labor voters descend on Brisbane to hash out their party's platform for the next three years, readying to debate some of the most contentious policies in federal politics.

title.children: The great Labor spectacle begins, as ALP hosts first national conference in government since Julia Gillard

image.altText: Brisbane cityscape

items.synopsis: The income limits that apply to social housing recipients in Queensland have remained unchanged since 2006. The state government has now ordered a review of the thresholds.

title.children: Income limits for social housing to be reviewed in Queensland

image.altText: A young man with short, dark hair and a contemplative expression on his face stands in a field.

items.synopsis: Victorian police officer Alex Prestney was on duty the day his brother and four of their colleagues died in a horrific crash with an appalling aftermath. Now he's harnessing the passion he shared with his sibling to try and spare others the same pain.

title.children: His brother's death shocked the nation and sparked outrage. Alex says it could have been him

image.altText: An aerial shot of a dilapidated old warship.

items.synopsis: A dilapidated Philippines ship intentionally run aground on a South China Sea reef to counter China's claim to the area could soon "succumb to the elements", an American security analyst says.

title.children: Philippines in a race against time to resupply a rusting hulk in the South China Sea

image.altText: A large crowd of people waiting at a train station

items.synopsis: Commuters faced long delays getting home after the Matildas' loss to England in the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Two charged over Sydney train chaos following Matildas' World Cup loss

image.altText: a large crowd gathering and letting off flares

items.synopsis: Football fans storm barricades and throw flares at Melbourne's Federation Square, which hit maximum capacity.

title.children: World Cup drama as fans storm barriers, throw flares at overflowing Federation Square

image.altText: Donald Bonney staring off

items.synopsis: A private hydro scheme in Tasmania's north-west is capable of powering 800 homes — but questions are being asked about the impact on neighbouring properties.

title.children: 'It's totally wrong': Trees are dying on Donald's property as pastures turn to bogs

image.altText: A woman and two children walk down a runway with an small plane behind them.

items.synopsis: It's something we rarely hear about in Australia – for good reason – but there are people living in witness protection programs across the nation.

title.children: New name, new history, new location: Is witness protection really like what we see on TV?

image.altText: A close-up of an embryo being surgically prodded

items.synopsis: Affected patients were alerted this week about the contamination at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital's fertility unit.

title.children: 'It's devastating': Embryos destroyed after bacterial outbreak at IVF clinic

image.altText: Will Forte as Reggie behind the wheel of a car with a dog in the background. Doug looks exasperated

items.synopsis: Starring Will Ferrell, Jamie Foxx and Australian actor Isla Fisher, Strays is an R-rated comedy about friendship that will have you howling with laughter.

title.children: Strays will leave you roaring with laughter and gasping in disbelief

image.altText: Telstra Shop signage outside Brisbane CBD store

items.synopsis: Negativity on Wall Street overnight is likely to send the local market lower after the US Federal Reserve flagged potential interest rate rises, noting inflation was still a "significant" risk to the economy. Follow live.

title.children: Telstra profit surges to $2bn, US plagued by 'significant' inflation concerns, ASX to fall ahead of latest unemployment data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB's CEO Ross McEwan has welcomed yesterday's National Cabinet deal that will see 1.2 million houses built over five years, starting from next July. The additional 200,000 homes are on top of the National Housing Accord target that was agreed on by state and territories last year, with $3 billion set aside for the fast-tracking of the builds. Speaking from the country music capital of Tamworth in northern NSW, Mr McEwan said the lack of housing is the biggest barrier that's standing in the way of businesses being able to fill job vacancies, and changes to the planning process across the states was needed. "I'd say it's [housing] the biggest issue that we've got across Australia," he told the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan. "So the government's spending time on it and it should be, I think, on the simplification of the planning process. "That's not to say we want houses built in the wrong places, but the simplification, taking 5, 10 years to get a development up and running is just far too long in this environment and we need action pretty quickly. "When you come out to places like Tamworth and you see the facilities out here, with the sporting facilities, the council facilities, you realise it’s well served, but it’s getting people into these communities and finding the housing ... that is the biggest problem ." You can listen to Ross McEwan's full chat with Peter Ryan below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB boss says housing is the 'biggest issue' facing the economy

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Our largest energy retailer, Origin Energy has also posted their results this morning, recording a profit of $1.1 billion for the last financial year. It's a return to profitability for the energy company, which reported a loss of $1.4 billion last year. The energy retailer notes that its underlying earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) for energy markets increased by $637 million to $1.038 billion, and that its electricity profits rose as higher wholesale energy costs were recovered in tariffs and the "optimisation of the energy supply portfolio". The gains also come despite the global energy crunch, which has sent gas and electricity prices higher. It also forecasts more growth in the coming financial year, before moderating in the 2025 financial year. Origin will pay shareholders a fully-franked final dividend of 20 cents per share .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy profits hit $1.1 billion

children.content: Our largest energy retailer,
Origin Energy
has also posted their results this morning, recording a
profit of $1.1 billion
for the last financial year.
It's a return to profitability for the energy company, which reported a
loss of $1.4 billion last year
The energy retailer notes that its underlying earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) for
energy markets increased by $637 million to $1.038 billion
, and that its electricity profits rose as higher wholesale energy costs were recovered in tariffs and the "optimisation of the energy supply portfolio".
The gains also come despite the global energy crunch, which has sent gas and electricity prices higher.
It also forecasts
more growth in the coming financial year
, before moderating in the 2025 financial year.
Origin will pay shareholders a
fully-franked final dividend of 20 cents per share

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Telstra's full-year results are just out and its a big year for Australia's dominant telco, with net profit up 13.1% to $2.05 billion. Profit attributable to Telstra equity holders was up 14.2% to $1.93 billion. The rise in profit was based on a 5.4% increase in total income to $23.2 billion. "We remain disciplined on reducing our costs, particularly considering the external economic environment," said Telstra's CEO Vicki Brady. Ms Brady said her priority was to continue to improve customer experience and further reduce complaints to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, which the company said fell by more than a third on the previous year. Telstra also revealed that its current plan is to retain ownership of its infrastructure business, InfraCo Fixed, "for at least the medium term" after it was structurally separated out from the rest of the firm earlier this year, meaning a sale or public share float is off the table for now. The telco was cautious in its guidance, predicting total income should be slightly higher than current levels but could be lower ($22.8 to $24.8 billion), while underlying profits before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of $8.2-8.4 billion would be slightly higher than this year's $8 billion result. "While our cost reduction ambition is being challenged by high inflation, we still expect to achieve the large majority of this by financial year 2025," added Ms Brady. The company will pay a fully-franked final dividend of 8.5 cents per share bringing total dividends for the year to 17 cents, slightly up on last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telstra profit jumps 13 per cent, passes $2b

The rise in profit was based on a
5.4% increase in total income to $23.2 billion
"We remain disciplined on reducing our costs, particularly considering the external economic environment," said Telstra's CEO Vicki Brady.

Ms Brady said her priority was to continue to improve customer experience and further reduce complaints to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, which the company said fell by more than a third on the previous year.
Telstra also revealed that its current plan is to
retain ownership of its infrastructure business, InfraCo Fixed, "for at least the medium term"
after it was structurally separated out from the rest of the firm earlier this year, meaning a sale or public share float is off the table for now.
The telco was
cautious in its guidance

, predicting total income should be slightly higher than current levels but could be lower ($22.8 to $24.8 billion), while underlying profits before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of $8.2-8.4 billion would be slightly higher than this year's $8 billion result.
"While our cost reduction ambition is being challenged by high inflation, we still expect to achieve the large majority of this by financial year 2025," added Ms Brady.
The company will pay a
fully-franked final dividend of 8.5 cents per share
bringing total dividends for the year to 17 cents, slightly up on last year.

items.synopsis: Georgia has a long history of tension with its northern neighbour, exacerbated by the conflict in Ukraine.

title.children: The Killers upset Georgian fans by bringing Russian on stage

image.altText: A man with long white hair and white beard, with glasses, smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Sunil Badami remembers his uncle wowing the public with 'miracles' like bending spoons with his mind. Decades later, he learnt the devastating secret his uncle hid.

title.children: Sunil's uncle lived a public life, eating fire and levitating. But he carried a private grief

image.altText: A man surrounded by a mob hits a piece of furniture on fire with a stick.

items.synopsis: A Muslim crowd is accused of attacking churches with sledgehammers and setting them on fire, while hundreds blocked a highway over accusations Christians desecrated the Koran.

title.children: Mob sets churches on fire in Pakistan, hundreds take to streets over blasphemy claims

image.altText: A graphic containing a silhouette of a side profile of a woman's face. A road sign that says 'Palmerston' is in the background

items.synopsis: The inquest heard Miss Yunupiŋu – as she is known for cultural reasons –at times felt "hopeless and helpless" as she was pressured to return to her partner, despite his constant violent abuse.

title.children: 'She wasn't going to get peace': Woman coerced into staying in deadly relationship, coroner hears

image.altText: A blue road train drives along a red dirt road, dust in its wake, blue sky with a few clouds, trees.

items.synopsis: In dry and dusty outback Queensland, rain is always a welcome sight. But for a region where the only means of transportation is a dirt road, even small falls can leave a mess.

title.children: Road trips through outback Australia are big bucket list items, but unsealed roads can cause havoc

image.altText: Car and horse float crash and Ben Yole composite image.

items.synopsis: The young driver of a car that crashed while towing an unregistered horse float, injuring five people and killing four horses, is charged with driving offences — as several of those involved in the crash battle for compensation.

title.children: Young horse float driver for Ben Yole charged over crash that injured passengers, killed horses

image.altText: A green and pink parrot on a perch inside a home

items.synopsis: When Conor Mulligan's pet parrot went missing in suburban Adelaide, he did what many pet owners do and distributed posters around the area, but never imagined it would lead to "one of the scariest situations" he had ever been in.

title.children: Conor offered a reward for his missing bird. Days later he was being ambushed
